enrich_metadata.label: San Francisco
enrich_metadata.abstract: San Francisco (/sæn frənˈsɪskoʊ/), officially the City and County of San Francisco, is the cultural, commercial, and financial center of Northern California and the only consolidated city-county in California. San Francisco encompasses a land area of about 46.9 square miles (121 km2) on the northern end of the San Francisco Peninsula, which makes it the smallest county in the state. It has a density of about 18,187 people per square mile (7,022 people per km2), making it the most densely settled large city (population greater than 200,000) in the state of California and the second-most densely populated major city in the United States after New York City. San Francisco is the fourth-most populous city in California, after Los Angeles, San Diego and San Jose, and the 13th-most populous city in the United States—with a Census-estimated 2014 population of 852,469. The city and its surrounding areas are known as the San Francisco Bay Area, and are a part of the larger OMB designated San Jose-San Francisco-Oakland combined statistical area, the fifth most populous in the nation with an estimated population of 8.6 million. San Francisco (Spanish for Saint Francis) was founded on June 29, 1776, when colonists from Spain established Presidio of San Francisco at the Golden Gate and Mission San Francisco de Asís named for St. Francis of Assisi a few miles away. The California Gold Rush of 1849 brought rapid growth, making it the largest city on the West Coast at the time. San Francisco became a consolidated city-county in 1856.After three-quarters of the city was destroyed by the 1906 earthquake and fire, San Francisco was quickly rebuilt, hosting the Panama-Pacific International Exposition nine years later. In World War II, San Francisco was the port of embarkation for service members shipping out to the Pacific Theater. After the war, the confluence of returning servicemen, massive immigration, liberalizing attitudes, along with the rise of the "hippie" counterculture, the Sexual Revolution, the Peace Movement growing from opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War, and other factors led to the Summer of Love and the gay rights movement, cementing San Francisco as a center of liberal activism in the United States. Politically, the city votes strongly along liberal Democratic Party lines. San Francisco is a popular tourist destination, known for its cool summers, fog, steep rolling hills, eclectic mix of architecture, and landmarks including the Golden Gate Bridge, cable cars, the former Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary, Fisherman's Wharf, and its Chinatown district. San Francisco is also the headquarters of five major banking institutions and various other companies such as Levi Strauss & Co., Gap Inc., Salesforce.com, Dropbox, Reddit, Square, Inc., Dolby, Airbnb, Weebly, Pacific Gas and Electric Company, Yelp, Pinterest, Twitter, Uber, Mozilla, Wikimedia Foundation, and Craigslist. It has several nicknames, including "The City by the Bay", "Fog City", "San Fran", and "Frisco", as well as older ones like "The City that Knows How", "Baghdad by the Bay", and "The Paris of the West". As of 2015, San Francisco was ranked high on world livability rankings.

enrich_metadata.label: Escondido, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Escondido, San Diego County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Escondido (/ˌɛskənˈdiːdoʊ/ ES-kən-DEE-doh) is a city located in San Diego County's North County region, 30 miles (48 km) northeast of Downtown San Diego, California. The city occupies a shallow valley ringed by rocky hills. Incorporated in 1888, it is one of the oldest cities in San Diego County. The city had a population of 143,911 at the 2010 census. Its municipal government set itself an operating budget limit of $426,289,048 for the fiscal year 2010–2011. The city is known as Eskondiid in Diegueño.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Escondido,_California
enrich_metadata.comment: Escondido (/ˌɛskənˈdiːdoʊ/ ES-kən-DEE-doh) is a city located in San Diego County's North County region, 30 miles (48 km) northeast of Downtown San Diego, California. The city occupies a shallow valley ringed by rocky hills. Incorporated in 1888, it is one of the oldest cities in San Diego County. The city had a population of 143,911 at the 2010 census. Its municipal government set itself an operating budget limit of $426,289,048 for the fiscal year 2010–2011. The city is known as Eskondiid in Diegueño.

enrich_metadata.label: Beverly Hills, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Beverly Hills, Los Angeles County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Beverly Hills is a city in Los Angeles County, California, United States, surrounded by the cities of Los Angeles and West Hollywood. Originally a Spanish ranch where lima beans were grown, Beverly Hills was incorporated in 1914 by a group of investors who had failed to find oil, but found water instead and eventually decided to develop it into a town. By 2013, its population had grown to 34,658. Sometimes referred to as "90210", one of its primary ZIP codes, it is home to many actors and celebrities. The city includes the Rodeo Drive shopping district and the Beverly Hills Oil Field.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Beverly_Hills,_California
enrich_metadata.comment: Beverly Hills is a city in Los Angeles County, California, United States, surrounded by the cities of Los Angeles and West Hollywood. Originally a Spanish ranch where lima beans were grown, Beverly Hills was incorporated in 1914 by a group of investors who had failed to find oil, but found water instead and eventually decided to develop it into a town. By 2013, its population had grown to 34,658. Sometimes referred to as "90210", one of its primary ZIP codes, it is home to many actors and celebrities. The city includes the Rodeo Drive shopping district and the Beverly Hills Oil Field.

enrich_metadata.mention_address: St. Helena, Napa County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: St. Helena (/ˌseɪnt hᵻˈliːnə/ saint hə-LEE-nə) (Wappo: Anakotanoma, "Bull Snake Village") is a city in Napa County, California. It is part of the North Bay region of the San Francisco Bay Area. The population was 5,814 at the 2010 census.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/St._Helena,_California
enrich_metadata.comment: St. Helena (/ˌseɪnt hᵻˈliːnə/ saint hə-LEE-nə) (Wappo: Anakotanoma, "Bull Snake Village") is a city in Napa County, California. It is part of the North Bay region of the San Francisco Bay Area. The population was 5,814 at the 2010 census.

enrich_metadata.label: San Diego
enrich_metadata.mention_address: San Diego, San Diego County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: San Diego /ˌsæn diːˈeɪɡoʊ/ (Spanish for "Saint Didacus") is a major city in California, on the coast of the Pacific Ocean in Southern California, approximately 120 miles (190 km) south of Los Angeles and immediately adjacent to the border with Mexico. With an estimated population of 1,381,069 as of July 1, 2014, San Diego is the eighth-largest city in the United States and second-largest in California. San Diego is the birthplace of California and is known for its mild year-round climate, natural deep-water harbor, extensive beaches, long association with the U.S. Navy, and recent emergence as a healthcare and biotechnology development center. Historically home to the Kumeyaay people, San Diego was the first site visited by Europeans on what is now the West Coast of the United States. Upon landing in San Diego Bay in 1542, Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo claimed the entire area for Spain, forming the basis for the settlement of Alta California 200 years later. The Presidio and Mission of San Diego, founded in 1769, formed the first European settlement in what is now California. In 1821, San Diego became part of newly independent Mexico, and in 1850, became part of the United States following the Mexican–American War and the admission of California to the union. The city is the seat of San Diego County and is the economic center of the region as well as the San Diego–Tijuana metropolitan area. San Diego's main economic engines are military and defense-related activities, tourism, international trade, and manufacturing. The presence of the University of California, San Diego (UCSD), with the affiliated UCSD Medical Center, has helped make the area a center of research in biotechnology.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/San_Diego

san diego.address: San Diego, San Diego County, California, United States of America

attraction_reviewComments: First time here. Until recently, I have never had friends buried here. Respect for our fallen veterans is displayed well here. When in Riverside, take some time to visit our... read more
Went to pay respects, and while there learned about the Medal Of Honor Memorial. It is worth the time to visit, and is well maintained.
Came here in April 2013 to visit my father's gravesite. He was a WWII vet, who moved from Midwest to LA in 1980s. Can't express how lovely the grounds are, and how meaningful it... read more
Great place to honor our countries heroes. Very quiet and a place of great respect, easy access from the freeway.
My parents are both buried here. My father served time in the Navy and our family was very proud of his service and being able to be Interred in this Military Cemetery. The... read more
I took a nice drive around the grounds on this gloomy rainy day. The cemetery is very well maintained and a respectful place for our honored veterens. The ponds, fountains and... read more
This park is close to our home. We frequently wander about this beautiful place. It is kept immaculate. It has one of four Metal of Honor Memorials in the United States. But, it... read more
A friend and co-worker from my first overseas assignment is buried here. Unlike other VA cemeteries the grave markers are all flush with the ground. It's a very nice, peaceful... read more
This place is beautiful and the service locations are all wonderful with some having stunning views. The locations for interment and inurment are wonderful.
I've visited this place every year for the past 12 years and it just keeps getting better and better. The grounds are well manicured and well maintained. Over time the desert... read more
Well organized, very somber and honoring. Clean restrooms (always a plus). Great staff. Well groomed grounds but being revamped. That was fine. Did not like the fact that... read more
This is by far, the most beautiful cemetery in all of California. Many war veterans and some of their spouses are buried here. On Memorial Day, all the markers have a USA flag... read more

enrich_metadata.abstract: San Marcos is a city in the North County region of San Diego County in the U.S. state of California. As of the 2010 census, the city's population was 83,781. It is the site of California State University, San Marcos. The city is bordered by Escondido to the east, Encinitas to the southwest, Carlsbad to the west, and Vista to the northeast.

enrich_metadata.label: Oakland, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Oakland, Alameda County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Oakland /ˈoʊklənd/ is a major West Coast port city in the U.S. state of California. Oakland is the third largest city in the San Francisco Bay Area, the eighth-largest city in California, and the 45th-largest city in the U.S. with a population of 413,775 as of 2014. It serves as a trade center for the San Francisco Bay Area; its Port of Oakland is the busiest port for San Francisco Bay, all of Northern California, and fifth busiest in the United States. Incorporated in 1852, Oakland is the county seat of Alameda County. It is also the principal city of the Bay Area Region known as the East Bay. The city is situated directly across the bay, six miles (9.7 km) east of San Francisco. Oakland's territory covers what was once a mosaic of coastal terrace prairie, oak woodland, and north coastal scrub. Its land served as a rich resource when its hillside oak and redwood timber were logged to build San Francisco, and Oakland's fertile flatland soils helped it become a prolific agricultural region. In the late 1860s, Oakland was selected as the western terminal of the Transcontinental Railroad. Following the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, many San Franciscans relocated to Oakland, enlarging the city's population, increasing its housing stock and improving its infrastructure. It continued to grow in the 20th century with its busy port, shipyards, and a thriving automobile manufacturing industry. Oakland is known for its sustainability practices, including a top ranking for usage of electricity from renewable resources. Oakland is also known for its history of political activism, as well as its professional sports franchises and major corporations, which include health care, dot-com companies and manufacturers of household products. In addition, thanks to a steady influx of immigrants during the 20th century, along with thousands of African-American war-industry workers who relocated from the Deep South during the 1940s, Oakland is one of the most ethnically diverse major cities in the country.

Incorporated in 1852, Oakland is the county seat of Alameda County. It is also the principal city of the Bay Area Region known as the East Bay. The city is situated directly across the bay, six miles (9.7 km) east of San Francisco.

enrich_metadata.label: Woodland, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Woodland is the county seat of Yolo County, California, located approximately 15 miles (24 km) northwest of Sacramento, and is a part of the Sacramento - Arden-Arcade - Roseville Metropolitan Statistical Area. The population was 55,468 at the 2010 census. Woodland's origins trace back to 1850 when California gained its statehood and Yolo County was established. Since the town started growing in population and resources, it has not stopped. The area was well irrigated due to the efforts of James Moore, and this drew people out to try their hand at farming. The endeavor was successful as people found the soil in the area very fertile. The city gained a federal post office and the next year the county seat was moved from Washington (present day West Sacramento, California) to Woodland after Washington was flooded. The addition of a railroad line, the close proximity to Sacramento, and the more recent addition of Interstate 5, helped create a thriving city.

enrich_metadata.label: Berkeley, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Berkeley (/ˈbɜːrkliː/ BURK-lee) is a city on the east shore of San Francisco Bay in northern Alameda County, California. It is named after the 18th-century Anglo-Irish bishop and philosopher George Berkeley. It borders the cities of Oakland and Emeryville to the south and the city of Albany and unincorporated community of Kensington to the north. Its eastern border with Contra Costa County generally follows the ridge of the Berkeley Hills. Its population at the 2010 census was 112,580. Berkeley is the site of the oldest campus in the University of California system – the University of California, Berkeley – of the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory which is managed and operated by the university, and the Graduate Theological Union. It is one of the most politically liberal cities in the United States.

enrich_metadata.label: Monrovia, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Monrovia is a city located in the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains in the San Gabriel Valley of Los Angeles County, California, United States. The population was 36,590 at the 2010 census, down from 36,929 in 2000. Monrovia has been used for filming TV shows, movies and commercials.

The epitome of Hollywood. Best views from Griffith Park or Griffith Observatory. Easy to drive to although local hotels can also take you there.
I loved Hollywood! It's energetic and fast-paced and fun to walk around. Everyone should see Hollywood at least once in his/her lifetime. There's lots to do and see.

attraction_reviewComments: This area is for youngster and hipster. Party on weekend is crazy...time to time I see people get thrown out because they were so drunk!! ... but its all good fun.
(Although the folks in Del Mar will argue about this.) Best food, best good times, best and most affordable/clean places to stay, best nightlife.
I love California beaches. I like this beach for the diversity of the people, the historic pier, the sand quality, ease of parking, and proximity to restaurants and businesses... read more
PB is known for it's nightlife. But it is also a very diverse community with families and couples. Ton's to do - surfing, walking, biking. Many interesting restaurants and... read more
We stayed at a great hotel on the beach. Very convenient location to everywhere in San Diego who want to go
We went for an early morning walk. It was the weekend and we were glad we got up early. Parking would have been an issue. The water is chilly for us Texans. But we loved the... read more
Pacific Beach is a great "beachy" area in San Diego. It is big enough where you have tons of restaurants, bars, stores, services etc.. and the beaches are big and very enjoyable... read more
Pacific Beach is just north of Mission Beach, and the beaches themselves are very similar. The biggest differences is really the people, the parking, and the surrounding shops... read more
Lots of young people and energy on this beach. No smoking and drinking on the beach itself, so that may be a plus or downside for some of us. North of the crystal pier is where... read more
Always a great beach to walk and enjoy the Pacific.
The beach is beautiful, clean, nice place to visit, has big waves, great for surfing and swimming, has nice places to eat along the beach.
Very nice beach, and relatively uncrowded for Comic Con weekend. Really clean and pretty.
More of your "public beach" feel with a wide mix of patrons. This is your surfer beach and a great place to watch people catch waves. Very nice in the late afternoon.
Great for surf/sun/sand, the beach and town are all for fun. Definitely for the college kids and young adults, this place can be alittle hectic, tons of shops, food, and fun... read more
Maybe a bit crowded for the older folks, but endless fun and things to do. Walk across the street to the bay, take surfing lessons, go sailing, great food and best of all watch... read more
We staying in Pacific Beach & there was so much to do & see. Just walking up & down the beach was great fun but the shops & restaurants were very plentiful!
I love this place were staying in a condo right on the beach, surf was great I took my first lesson with Ryan from PB surf school absolutely amazing place people are drunk and... read more

smallish beach, but perfect. Waves were good enough for plenty of surfers (in March), yet gentle enough for wading/swimming. Excellent sand quality, perfect for beach volleyball... read more
Cool beach where you will see lots of surfers as well as people just hanging on the sand. Tons of bars, restaurants and shopping across the street from the beach! Best part- there... read more
Our stay was great! We walked, walked some more, and even more. The beach is clean, a lot of seaweed washed up on the shore, but plenty of space to walk around it. We walked to... read more
Stayed at 725 Jamaica Ct. Had a great time. Had a view of the ocean from second floor. Very close to the boardwalk and beach. Would recommend to all my friends. We were there five... read more
This is a nice beach, seemed to have fewer children running around and more sunbathers. Nice to catch some rays and take in the view/sounds of the ocean without the screaming of... read more
We had started out trying to go to mission beach and Belmont park, but it was crazy crowded and we could find NO parking. So we kept going until we got to pacific beach, and I'm... read more
So, I truely know the best about PB as us locals call it, I live here. Most people crowd down south in Mission Beach towards the roller coaster. But the farther north you go... read more
This is a southern California beach of the imagination, at least of my imagination. Surfers and boogie boarders in the ocean, people fishing off the pier, joggers... read more
I love PB- great food and entertainment . But most of all the views of the ocean and the bay are top notch. The only draw back is the traffic - but it is worth it !
These San Diego beaches are some of the cleanest and friendliest beaches ever. Fantastic walk and plenty of fresh food vendors to stop for a snack or a craft beer.
Nice beach area, seems popular with the surfers, as there were quite a few. The weather was nice (still not used to this 75 in January), so quite a few people were out, doing... read more

Pacific Beach is not high end like La Jolla but has real California beach community charm. There is a long boardwalk along the beach with bars and restaurants. There are also many... read more
We stopped here on a Saturday and WOW it was crazy. We had a hard time finding a parking spot (about 3 blocks away on street parking). The beach is beautiful, wide, surfers... read more
Our family loved staying at Pacific Beach/Mission Bay. The area is lovely, fun, interesting and of course beautiful. Location is convenient to many great places to eat, sights and... read more
We stayed in a condo one block from the beach for 5 nights and 6 days and it was a blast! If you get the chance, visit the restaurant Firehouse, attached to an actual firehouse... read more
we loved the feel of this area. Very relaxed and unsophisticated. It was spring break and was full of young people hanging around, at the beach, surfing and having beers on the... read more
Being from Ny, this was my first time being to a beach with the Pacific Ocean. This beach is beautiful. Great scenery, eye candy and plenty of great shops. Do go, walk the ocean... read more
We really enjoyed walking along Pacific Beach watching the joggers and more serious runners as well as the surfers. The waves were awesome and watching these surfers challenge... read more
Spent month of March exploring this area from our comfortable condo at Capri by the Sea. We are older than most people here but loved walking the strand every day and watching... read more
We were in San Diego for thanksgiving. We got lucky and the weather was beautiful. The beach not crowded at all compared to the summer. The water was even still warm enough for... read more
Lovely beach, not to crowded even in the summer, Great playe to surf for beginners, nice restaurants close by. You can often spot dolphins playing just of shore!
Busy on the weekends, but what beach isn't? The water is amazing and there were plenty of parking available in the area for a price.
It wasn't even summer when I got here but the sun was shining every day and it was perfect beach weather every day.
The best family friendly surfing beach in San Diego . It's very clean with a laid back atmosphere. Our favorite beach.
Beautiful views of the Pacific Ocean and walks with lots of sights to see.Take time to enjoy the ocean and surfers.
Big, wide beach. Make sure you don't try to swim in the surfing section. Beach and water were clean and there is plenty of room so you don't feel crowded.
It's a nice beach, with great restaurants and bar. A lot of young and beautiful people, sports bar are everywhere. And the sunset from there is gorgeous.
Pacific beach is one of the beaches on the San Diego bay stretch and is popular with families for its low tide and smooth sand. One can start or terminate their bay walk at this... read more
Wonderful area of San Diego with nice shops and restrurants. Readily available grocery and drug stores. Clean and friendly. Watch out for summer afternoon traffic leaving... read more
Bring your hiking shoes..Amazing views, cliffs steep beachfront walks..Lovely shops and a neat little local village feel just 4 miles fom bustling San Diego..Parking free is a... read more
Pacific beach is a typical California beach community. The main area has bars, restaurants and of course surf shops. I tend to goo too the northern part of the beach where most of... read more
Great location. Accessible via public transportation. Bathhouse and outdoor showers. Lifeguard station. Restaurants/bars very close.
Pacific Beach is the middle class version of La Jolla. There are some cute bungalows and a tone of places to eat. The beach is also amazing. Wear good shoes so that you can walk... read more
We love this place. We go once a year to San Diego to see the granddaughter and usually stay in the PB area. The restaurants are great and the atmosphere is wonderful. The path... read more
Pacific beach is a great place to beach, but also a great place to stay. Once you get here, you rarely need to use your car, because everything is within walking distance! Aside... read more
Great location. Food, hotel, shopping. We loved for our Xmas visit. Central to going wherever you want & traffic wasn't too bad.
Pacific and Mission Beach are beautiful areas in San Diego. Beautiful views. Great surfing. Affordable. If you want 5 star restaurants and spas--you do not want this--go... read more

enrich_metadata.mention_address: Burbank, Los Angeles County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Burbank is a city in Los Angeles County in Southern California, United States, 12 miles (19 km) northwest of downtown Los Angeles. The population at the 2010 census was 103,340. Billed as the "Media Capital of the World" and only a few miles northeast of Hollywood, numerous media and entertainment companies are headquartered or have significant production facilities in Burbank, including The Walt Disney Company, Warner Bros. Entertainment, ABC Studios, ABC Family, Marvel Studios, Nickelodeon, NBC, and Insomniac Games. The city is also home to Bob Hope Airport. Burbank also holds a special place in aerospace history since Lockheed's Skunk Works in Burbank produced some of the most secret and technologically advanced airplanes, including the U-2 spy planes that uncovered the Soviet Union missile components in Cuba. Burbank consists of two distinct areas: a downtown, in the foothills of the Verdugo Mountains, and flatlands, at the east end of the San Fernando Valley. At one time, it was referred to as "Beautiful Downtown Burbank" on Laugh-In and The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson. The city was named after David Burbank, a New Hampshire-born dentist and entrepreneur.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Burbank,_California
